entry.et: Middle English, from Old English wund; akin to Old High German wunta wound

def.dt: :an injury to the body (as from violence, accident, or surgery) that typically involves laceration or breaking of a membrane (as the skin) and usually damage to underlying tissues
:a cut or breach in a plant usually due to an external agent
:a mental or emotional hurt or blow
:something resembling a wound in appearance or effect
:a rift in or blow to a political body or social group
:to cause a wound to or in
:to inflict a wound
:to detect or follow by scent
:to expose to the air or wind :dry by exposing to air
:to make short of breath
:to regulate the wind supply of (an organ pipe)
:to rest (as a horse) in order to allow the breath to be recovered
:to scent game
:to pause for breath
:to cause (as a horn) to sound by blowing :blow
:to sound (as a call or note) on a horn wound a rousing call R. L. Stevenson
:to produce a sound on a horn

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English windan to twist, move with speed or force, brandish; akin to Old High German wintan to wind, Umbrian ohavendu let him turn aside

def.dt: :weave
:entangle involve
:to introduce sinuously or stealthily :insinuate
:to encircle or cover with something pliable :bind with loops or layers
:to turn completely or repeatedly about an object :coil twine
:to hoist or haul by means of a rope or chain and a windlass
:to move (a ship) by hauling on a capstan
:to tighten the spring of wind a clock
:to make tighter :tighten tune
:crank
:to raise to a high level (as of excitement or tension) usually used with up
:to cause to move in a curving line or path
:to turn the course of
:to lead (a person) as one wishes
:to cause (as a ship) to change direction :turn
:to turn (a ship) end for end
:to traverse on a curving course the river winds the valley
:to effect by or as if by curving
:bend warp
:to have a curving course or shape :extend in curves
:to proceed as if by winding
:to move so as to encircle something
:to turn when lying at anchor
:an injury involving penetration of the body musculature without damage to bones or internal organs
:to draw gradually toward an end the party was winding down
:relax unwind wind down with a good book
:to cause a gradual lessening of usually with the intention of bringing to an end
:to bring to a conclusion :end
:to put in order for the purpose of bringing to an end winds up the meeting
:to effectuate the winding up of
:to come to a conclusion
:to arrive in a place, situation, or condition at the end or as a result of a course of action wound up as millionaires
:to make a pitching windup
